questions.question: Neither James nor his children ………………………. English.
questions.description: When we connect a singular noun and a plural noun with neither/nor, the verb agrees in number and person with the noun following nor.

questions.question: Neither Sam nor his brother ………………………
questions.description: When we connect two singular nouns with neither/nor, the verb is singular.

questions.question: The farmer along with his children ……………………. hard day and night.
questions.description: When we connect two nouns with along with, the verb agrees with the former.

questions.question: Neither you nor he ……………………….. capable of doing this.
questions.description: When we connect two pronouns with neither/nor, the verb agrees in number and person with the pronoun following nor.

questions.question: The writer and orator ……………………. no more.
questions.description: Here both nouns refer to the same person and hence we use a singular verb. If they referred to different persons, we would use the article before each noun.

questions.question: The man as well as his wife …………………….. guilty.
questions.description: When we connect two nouns with as well as, the verb agrees with the former in number and person.

questions.question: Being bilingual ……………………….. an advantage in the modern world.
questions.description: Here the subject is the gerund phrase being bilingual. It is considered singular.

questions.question: When we were children, we ……………………… long hours playing.
How they escaped ……………………. a mystery.
questions.description: When the subject is a noun clause, the verb is singular.

questions.question: Despite ………………………. rich, he is not happy.
Neither you nor I ………………………….. right.
questions.description: When we connect two pronouns with neither/nor, the verb agrees with the pronoun following nor.
